il.name: Passover (Day 1)
il.description: During Passover, the Jewish people remember the liberation of the Israelites from slavery, their exodus from Egypt, and that their first-born children were spared during the 10th plague, as told in the Haggadah.

ru.name: Orthodox Christmas Day
ru.description: Many Russians celebrate Christmas Day on January 7 in the Gregorian calendar, which corresponds to December 25 in the Julian calendar.

ru.name: New Year Holiday
ru.description: New Year Holiday is a national holiday in Russia

ru.name: Defender of the Fatherland Day
ru.description: Many Russians celebrate Defender of the Fatherland Day on February 23, when they honor military forces and veterans.

ru.name: International Women's Day
ru.description: Many Russians pay tribute to women’s role in Russian society by celebrating International Women’s Day on March 8.

ru.name: Spring and Labor Day
ru.description: For many Russians, Spring and Labor Day, which falls on May 1, is a family holiday and a time for relaxation.

ru.name: Substitute Holiday for New Year Holiday
ru.description: Substitute Holiday for New Year Holiday is a substitute holiday in Russia

ru.name: Substitute Holiday for Defender of the Fatherland Day
ru.description: Substitute Holiday for Defender of the Fatherland Day is a substitute holiday in Russia

ru.name: Victory Day
ru.description: One of the biggest Russian holidays, Victory Day, marks Germany’s surrender to the Soviet Union in 1945, ending one of the bloodiest wars in Russia’s history.

ru.name: Russia Day
ru.description: Russia Day, annually celebrated on June 12, marks the beginning of democratic reforms in Russia and is one of the newest holidays in the Russian Federation.

ru.name: Substitute Holiday for International Women's Day
ru.description: Substitute Holiday for International Women's Day is a substitute holiday in Russia

ru.name: Unity Day Holiday
ru.description: Unity Day Holiday is a national holiday in Russia

ru.name: Unity Day
ru.description: Unity Day, which is on November 4, is one of the newest and the most controversial holidays in Russia.

ru.name: Substitute Holiday for New Year Holiday

hr.name: New Year's Day
hr.description: New Year’s Day is the first day of the year, or January 1, in the Gregorian calendar.

hr.name: Epiphany
hr.description: Epiphany is a Christian holiday celebrated globally on January 6 each year. It commemorates two events recorded in the Bible: the three wise men’s visit to baby Jesus; and Jesus’ baptism.

hr.name: Easter Sunday
hr.description: Easter Sunday commemorates Jesus Christ’s resurrection, according to Christian belief.

hr.name: Easter Monday
hr.description: Easter Monday is the day after Easter Sunday.

hr.name: Labor Day / May Day
hr.description: Labor Day, International Workers' Day, and May Day, is a day off for workers in many countries around the world.

hr.name: Statehood Day
hr.description: Statehood Day is a national holiday in Croatia

hr.name: Corpus Christi
hr.description: Corpus Christi is a Christian feast in honor of the Holy Eucharist.

hr.name: Day of Antifascist Struggle
hr.description: Day of Antifascist Struggle is a national holiday in Croatia

hr.name: Victory Day
hr.description: Victory Day is a national holiday in Croatia

hr.name: Assumption of Mary
hr.description: The Christian feast of the Assumption of Mary is on or around Aug 15 in most countries. A few celebrate Assumption Day at other times of the year.

hr.name: All Saints' Day
hr.description: Many churches honor all their saints on All Saints' Day, also known as All Hallows' Day.

hr.name: Remembrance Day
hr.description: Remembrance Day is a national holiday in Croatia

hr.name: Christmas Day
hr.description: Christmas Day is one of the biggest Christian celebrations and falls on December 25 in the Gregorian calendar.

hr.name: St Stephen's Day
hr.description: St Stephen's Day is a national holiday in Croatia

es.name: New Year's Day
es.description: New Year’s Day is the first day of the year, or January 1, in the Gregorian calendar.

es.name: Epiphany
es.description: Epiphany is a public holiday and the day most Christmas presentes are exchanged in Spain.

es.name: Good Friday
es.description: Good Friday is a global Christian observance two days before Easter Sunday.

es.name: Labor Day / May Day
es.description: Labor Day, International Workers' Day, and May Day, is a day off for workers in many countries around the world.

es.name: Assumption of Mary
es.description: The Christian feast of the Assumption of Mary is on or around Aug 15 in most countries. A few celebrate Assumption Day at other times of the year.

es.name: Hispanic Day observed
es.description: Hispanic Day marks the anniversary of the date that Christopher Columbus first set foot in the Americas. It is a public holiday in Spain on October 12.

es.name: All Saints' Day
es.description: Many churches honor all their saints on All Saints' Day, also known as All Hallows' Day.

es.name: Constitution Day
es.description: Constitution Day marks the anniversary of the referendum to approve the Spanish Constitution and is a public holiday in Spain.

es.name: Immaculate Conception
es.description: The Feast of the Immaculate Conception is a Christian observance on December 8 each year.

es.name: Christmas Day
es.description: Christmas Day is one of the biggest Christian celebrations and falls on December 25 in the Gregorian calendar.

cz.name: Easter Monday

ro.name: New Year's Day
ro.description: New Year’s Day (Anul Nou) and the following day, on January 1 and 2 respectively, are annual holidays in Romania.

ro.name: Day after New Year's Day
ro.description: Both New Year’s Day (Anul Nou) and the following day, on January 1 and 2 respectively, are annual holidays in Romania.

ro.name: Epiphany
ro.description: Epiphany is a Christian holiday celebrated globally on January 6 each year. It commemorates two events recorded in the Bible: the three wise men’s visit to baby Jesus; and Jesus’ baptism.

ro.name: Synaxis of St. John the Baptist
ro.description: Synaxis of St. John the Baptist is a national holiday and Orthodox holiday in Romania

ro.name: Unification Day
ro.description: Unification Day celebrates the political union between Wallachia and Moldavia, which is deemed as the foundation of modern Romania.

ro.name: Orthodox Good Friday
ro.description: Millions of Orthodox Christians around the world annually observe Good Friday to commemorate the events leading up to Jesus Christ's crucifixion.

ro.name: Orthodox Easter Day
ro.description: Easter (Paștele) is both a religious and a national holiday in Romania. The Easter date is based on the Orthodox Christian Church’s calendar.

ro.name: Orthodox Easter Monday
ro.description: The Day after Easter (Paștele) is both a religious and a national holiday in Romania. The Easter date is based on the Orthodox Christian Church’s calendar.

ro.name: Labor Day / May Day
ro.description: Labor Day (Ziua muncii) is a national public holiday in Romania on May 1 each year.

ro.name: Children's Day
ro.description: Children’s Day (Ziua Copilului) is annually celebrated on June 1 in Romania.

ro.name: Orthodox Pentecost
ro.description: Many Christians in Romania celebrate the Pentecost (Rusalii or Rusaliile) public holiday, also known as Whitsunday or Whit Sunday.

ro.name: Orthodox Pentecost Monday
ro.description: Many Christians celebrate the Whit Monday (Rusalii or Rusaliile) public holiday in Romania.

ro.name: St Mary's Day
ro.description: The feast day of the Assumption of Mary is a national holiday in Romania on August 15 every year.

ro.name: St Andrew's Day
ro.description: St Andrew’s Day (Ziua Sfântului Andrei) is a national holiday in Romania on November 30 every year.

ro.name: National Day
ro.description: National Day in Romania, also called Unification Day, is an annual public holiday to remember when the country’s provinces became united on December 1, 1918.

ro.name: Christmas Day
ro.description: Christmas Day is a Christian holiday to celebrate Jesus Christ’s birth in Romania and falls on December 25 every year.

ro.name: Second day of Christmas
ro.description: The second day of Christmas falls on December 26 and is part of a two-day Christian holiday in Romania to celebrate Jesus Christ’s birth.

it.name: New Year's Day
it.description: New Year’s Day is celebrated in Italy on January 1 each year.

it.name: Epiphany
it.description: Epiphany is a national holiday in Italy celebrated annually on January 6.

it.name: Easter Sunday
it.description: Easter Day is a public holiday that is celebrated widely throughout Italy each year.

it.name: Easter Monday
it.description: Easter Monday is a public holiday in Italy that is celebrated annually on the day after Easter Day.

it.name: Liberation Day
it.description: Celebrated on April 25 each year, Italy’s Liberation Day commemorates when the Allied troops liberated the country from the Nazi occupation during World War II.

it.name: Labor Day / May Day
it.description: Labor Day is a national holiday annually held in Italy on May 1.

it.name: Republic Day
it.description: Italy’s Republic Day is an annual public holiday on June 2 to commemorates the date Italians voted for their country end the monarchy and become a republic.

it.name: Assumption of Mary
it.description: Assumption Day, also known as the Feast of the Assumption, is an annual public holiday in Italy on August 15.

it.name: All Saints' Day
it.description: In Italy All Saints’ Day is a national public holiday celebrated on November 1 to commemorate the Catholic saints.

it.name: Feast of the Immaculate Conception
it.description: Immaculate Conception Day is a nationwide holiday in Italy on December 8 that celebrates the belief that Jesus’ mother Mary is “free of sin”.

it.name: Christmas Day
it.description: Christmas Day is a public holiday in Italy on December 25 to celebrate the birth of Jesus Christ.

it.name: St. Stephen's Day
it.description: St Stephen’s Day is a public holiday in Italy on December 26.
